title: Bales v. Judelsohn
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Frankie Bales and Sandra Bales, Respondents,
v.
Robert Judelsohn, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-509
Submitted June 1, 2005 â€“ Filed August 30, 2005Â 

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Jay S. Masty, of Goose Creek, for Appellant.
Mark Andrew Redmond, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Frankie and Sandra Bales brought an action against Robert Judelsohn after Judelsohnâ€™s dog injured their dog.Â  The jury found for the Bales.Â  Judelsohn appeals.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]
FACTS
    In September 2000, Judelsohnâ€™s dog was involved in a fight with the Balesâ€™ dog.Â  Unfortunately, the Balesâ€™ dog was injured in the fight and had to be treated for various injuries, incurring a $1,258.10 veterinary bill.Â  The Bales brought an action seeking damages for reimbursement of the veterinary bill, lost wages, and emotional injuries.Â  The jury found Judelsohn liable for $5,000 in damages.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
        Judelsohn argues the trial court erred by submitting the issues of emotional damages and lost wages to the jury.Â  We agree.
        â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of this court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
        We have not found any jurisprudence in South Carolina that addresses damages resulting from an injury to a pet.Â  However, a limited number of cases decided throughout the United States have considered what damages are recoverable due to injuries to a dog.Â  Typically, the courts have limited the award of damages to the dogâ€™s market value in view of the general recognition of dogs as personal property.Â  4 Am. Jur. 2d Animals Â§Â§ 6 and 165 (1995); see State v. Langford, 55 S.C. 322, 33 S.E. 370 (1899). 
        A New York case, with facts similar to the case sub judice, held that the owner of a cat could not recover for mental distress after seeing it attacked by a dog because the dogâ€™s owner was not grossly negligent and did not willfully intend to cause the distress.Â  Buchanan v. Stout, 108 N.Y.S. 38 (N.Y. App. Div. 1908).Â  Any recovery of damages, the court concluded, would be limited to the pecuniary loss to the owner resulting from the death of her cat.Â  Id.;Â  but see 
        Peloquin v. Calcasieu Parish Police Jury, 
        367 So.2d 1246, 1251 (La. Ct. App. 1979) (holding that an owner of a animal may sue for damages for conversion thereof and â€œdamages may include awards for mental anguish, humiliation, etc. as well as special and/or actual damages.â€); 4 Am. Jur. 2d Animals Â§ 164 at 508 (1995) (stating that â€œ[a]lthough recovery has been denied for claims based upon sentimental or fanciful value placed on animals, damages for mental distress are a proper item of recovery for death or injury to animals such as . . . dogs, provided that the owner presents sufficient evidence of emotional distress.â€). 
        Therefore, we hold that South Carolina law does not support a cause of action for emotional distress for injury to oneâ€™s pet.Â  Furthermore, we hold that a claim for lost wages resulting from injury to an animal is not actionable because a dog is considered personal property under our law.Â  Thus, we modify the trial courtâ€™s judgment, awarding damages only for reimbursement of veterinary expenses in the amount of $1,258.10.
        AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
        HEARN, C.J., BEATTY, and SHORT, J.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Gregory Tucker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-510
Submitted June 1, 2005 â€“ Filed August 30, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attoney General W. Rutledge Martin, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Gregory Tucker was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping, and possession of a knife during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Tucker appeals, arguing the trial court erred in denying his challenge of the Stateâ€™s peremptory strikes.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Tucker, an African-American male, was indicted for first-degree criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping, first-degree burglary, and possession of a knife during the commission of a violent crime.Â  During jury selection for Tuckerâ€™s trial in March 2003, the State used its peremptory challenges to strike Juror #53, a black male; Juror #15, a black male; and Juror #142, a black female.Â  Before the jury was sworn, Tucker made a motion under Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986), challenging the Stateâ€™s use of its peremptory strikes to exclude black jurors.Â  The State explained that it struck Juror #53 because he had served time on a â€œcontempt charge for failure to pay child support.Â  He also had a Magistrate level drug conviction.â€Â  The State said it struck Juror #15 because the victim in this case was a female and the juror had made comments during the qualification process that elicited â€œa negative attitude toward (sic) women.â€Â  Finally, the State argued it struck Juror #142 because she had â€œ[m]agistrate level convictions for drugs and for breach of trust.â€Â  As evidence of pretext, Tucker pointed out that the third juror seated by both parties was a white male who had a magistrate level offense for driving under suspension.Â  The State explained that â€œthere may, based on witness testimony, be some evidence brought in with regards to drugs and thatâ€™s why [it] kept all drug convictions out.â€Â  The trial court held the State had shown â€œvalid reasons for striking the jurors that were excusedâ€ and denied Tuckerâ€™s motion.[2]
The jury found Tucker guilty of first-degree criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping, and possession of a knife during commission of a violent crime.Â  The jury acquitted him of the first-degree burglary charge.Â  Tucker made a motion for a new trial based on his challenge of the peremptory strikes.Â  Though no evidence of drugs came out at trial, the trial court denied Tuckerâ€™s motion for a new trial, finding Tucker did not show the strikes were pretextual. 
The trial court sentenced Tucker to 30 years imprisonment for criminal sexual conduct, 30 years concurrent for kidnapping, and 5 years consecutive for possession of a knife during the commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Tucker claims the trial court erred in denying his challenge to the Stateâ€™s peremptory strikes because they were racially motivated.Â  We disagree.
The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.Â  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 89 (1986); State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 211, 499 S.E.2d 209, 211 (1998).Â  As a result, a â€œtrial judge must hold a Batson hearing when members of a cognizable racial group or gender are struck and the opposing party requests a hearing.â€Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999).Â  Once a Batson hearing has been requested, the proponent of the strike must offer a race or gender-neutral explanation for excusing the juror.Â  Id.Â  In return, the opponent must show the race or gender-neutral explanation was mere pretext, which is generally established by showing the party did not strike a similarly situated member of another race or gender.Â  Id. at 629, 515 S.E.2d at 91.Â  
The opponent of the strike carries the ultimate burden of persuading the trial court the challenged party exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner.Â  State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 124, 470 S.E.2d 366, 372 (1996).Â  â€œIn deciding whether the opponent of a strike has carried the burden of persuasion, a court must undertake a sensitive inquiry into the circumstantial and direct evidence of intent.â€ Haigler, 334 S.C. at 629, 515 S.E.2d at 91.Â  â€œA strike must be examined in light of the circumstances under which it is exercised, including an examination of the explanations offered for other strikes.â€Â  Id.Â  Under some circumstances, the explanation given by the proponent may be so fundamentally implausible that the trial judge may determine the explanation was mere pretext, even without a showing of disparate treatment.Â  Id.Â  
Whether a Batson violation has occurred must be determined by examining the totality of the facts and circumstances in the record.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe trial courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful discrimination are accorded great deference and will be set aside on appeal only if clearly erroneous.â€Â  Id. at 630, 515 S.E.2d at 91.Â  Because the trial courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful discrimination rest largely upon an evaluation of the credibility of the attorney making the strikes, we give those findings great deference.Â  State v. Patterson, 307 S.C. 180, 182, 414 S.E.2d 155, 157 (1992).Â  However, where the record does not support the attorneyâ€™s stated reason for the strike, the trial courtâ€™s findings must be overturned.Â  Id. at 182-83, 414 S.E.2d at 157.
We hold Tucker did not carry his burden of persuasion in proving the State engaged in purposeful discrimination during the jury selection process.Â  In this case, the Stateâ€™s primary reason for striking two jurors was because they had drug convictions, and counsel for the State was concerned with these jurorsâ€™ reactions to testimony and evidence of drug use that potentially could come in during the trial of the case.Â  Though there is some confusion as to the criminal history of Juror #26, a white male, there is no doubt he did not have a drug conviction.[3]Â  Tucker did not point to any other seated jurors of another race who were similarly situated to the stricken venire persons.Â  The State struck the third juror for questionable comments regarding women, a potential problem because the victim was a female.Â  Therefore, the record contains no indication that the Stateâ€™s reasons for striking the three black jurors were motivated by purposeful discrimination.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., BEATTY, and SHORT, J.J., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Judge James Brogdon, Jr., qualified the jury, but Judge J. Michael Baxley presided over the trial itself.Â  
[3] During the Batson hearing, the State presented that Juror #26 had a six-year-old conviction for driving under suspension.Â  However, during the post-trial motions, the State did not correct Tucker when he represented to the trial court that Juror #26 had a conviction for driving under the influence.
